query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 «O Padre nostro, che ne’ cieli stai, 2 non circunscritto, ma per più amore 3 ch’ai primi effetti di là sù tu hai,
4 laudato sia ’l tuo nome e ’l tuo valore 5 da ogne creatura, com’ è degno 6 di render grazie al tuo dolce vapore.
query.result:
**English:**
1 "Our Father, who art in the heavens, 2 not circumscribed, but through greater love 3 than thou hast for the first effects from up there,
4 praised be thy name and thy worth 5 by every creature, as is worthy 6 to give thanks to thy sweet breath.
**Cornish:**
1 "O Tadn ni, neb yn y nebesow ow pesya, 2 nyns yw kynskryfys, mes rag moy karanteth 3 ages an kynsa effektys a'n uhella owth eus,
4 bennakys bos dha hanow ha dha werth 5 gans pub kreatur, avel yw dygthys 6 dhe rosya dhys rag dha dowr blas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Vegna ver’ noi la pace del tuo regno, 8 ché noi ad essa non potem da noi, 9 s’ella non vien, con tutto nostro ingegno.
query.result:
**English:**
7 May the peace of thy kingdom come to us, 8 for we cannot attain it by ourselves, 9 if it does not come, with all our ingenuity.
**Cornish:**
7 Dheugh dhe ni hedhyans a'ga rynos, 8 rag nyns yw possyf dhe ni dhe'y gavas ni honan, 9 mar nyns yw ow tos, gans pub ni hys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Come del suo voler li angeli tuoi 11 fan sacrificio a te, cantando osanna, 12 così facciano li uomini de’ suoi.
query.result:
**English:**
10 As thy angels make sacrifice to thee of their will, 11 singing hosanna, 12 so may men do of theirs.
**Cornish:**
10 Avel aga angylys a wra dhe'th offryn aga wolons dhys, 11 ow kanna osanna, 12 keth poos wra an dus a'ga wolons.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Dà oggi a noi la cotidiana manna, 14 sanza la qual per questo aspro diserto 15 a retro va chi più di gir s’affanna.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Give us this day our daily manna, 14 without which in this harsh desert 15 he who strives to go forward goes backward.
**Cornish:**
13 Ro dhyn ni hedhyw an manna pub dydh, 14 hebma neb nyns yw possyf dhe ni dhe drehedha an disert magh, 15 dhe'n neb a wra moy strif dhe drehedha a-dhyworth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 E come noi lo mal ch’avem sofferto 17 perdoniamo a ciascuno, e tu perdona 18 benigno, e non guardar lo nostro merto.
query.result:
**English:**
16 And as we pardon each one the evil that we have suffered, 17 do thou also pardon us, benign, and do not look at our merit.
**Cornish:**
16 Ha keth poos ny ni a bardon an drok a'n eus dhe dhugedha, 17 bardon dhyn ni, benyn, ha na wel an ni meret.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Nostra virtù che di legger s’adona, 20 non spermentar con l’antico avversaro, 21 ma libera da lui che sì la sprona.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Quest’ ultima preghiera, segnor caro, 23 già non si fa per noi, ché non bisogna, 24 ma per color che dietro a noi restaro».
query.result:
**English:**
22 This final prayer, dear Lord, 23 is no longer made for us, for it is not needed, 24 but for those who will remain after us.
**Cornish:**
22 An gwedh ma diwettha, Arluth ker, 23 nyns yw gwres ragoni, rag nyns yw keus, 24 mes rag an re beu yn-rag ni a wra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Così a sé e noi buona ramogna 26 quell’ ombre orando, andavan sotto ’l pondo, 27 simile a quel che talvolta si sogna,
28 disparmente angosciate tutte a tondo 29 e lasse su per la prima cornice, 30 purgando la caligine del mondo.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Thus praying for themselves and us, 26 those shades continued on their way beneath their burdens, 27 like those sometimes seen in dreams,
28 all variously distressed, circling around 29 and weary on the first ledge, 30 purging the darkness of the world.
**Cornish:**
25 Vel dhyn dha ha dhyn ni, 26 an keffrys-na hwella, a gavas orth an poos, 27 kepar ha’n re a wra gweleis yn-mes a-weyth,
28 dyffrans orth an poos oll an-gas, 29 ha blon orth an kynsa cornys, 30 ow purja tewlder an bys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Se di là sempre ben per noi si dice, 32 di qua che dire e far per lor si puote 33 da quei c’hanno al voler buona radice?
34 Ben si de’ loro atar lavar le note 35 che portar quinci, sì che, mondi e lievi, 36 possano uscire a le stellate ruote.
query.result:
**English:**
31 If good is always spoken of them there, 32 what can be said and done for them here 33 by those whose will is well-rooted?
34 Surely their loved ones should loosen the knots 35 that they carry from here, so that, cleansed and light, 36 they may ascend to the starry wheels.
**Cornish:**
31 Mar a wra lever dhyso dhyn allá, 32 pyth yw dhe lever dhe dhyso ha gweles 33 gans an re a wra gwreydh da voladh da?
34 Mes lever yw dhe’n kerens dhe dhyso an notys 35 a wra porthys owna, dhe wosa ha lowen, 36 dhe alla orth an keffrys steren.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 «Deh, se giustizia e pietà vi disgrievi 38 tosto, sì che possiate muover l’ala, 39 che secondo il disio vostro vi lievi,
40 mostrate da qual mano inver’ la scala 41 si va più corto; e se c’è più d’un varco, 42 quel ne ’nsegnate che men erto cala;
43 ché questi che vien meco, per lo ’ncarco 44 de la carne d’Adamo onde si veste, 45 al montar sù, contra sua voglia, è parco».
query.result:
**English:**
37 “Oh, if justice and pity move you, 38 quickly, so that you may move your wings 39 and rise according to your desire,
40 show us which way leads most directly to the stairway, 41 and if there is more than one passage, 42 teach us the one that descends less steeply,
43 for this man who comes with me, because of the burden 44 of the flesh of Adam that he wears, 45 is slow to climb, against his will.”
**Cornish:**
37 “Mar a wra jystyns ha trugarowgh dhe dhysgrivya 38 a-derow, dhe alla orth dhe wolow an askel, 39 kepar ha’th voladh dhe dhesel dhe dhe lowen,
40 dysk dhe dhyn ni orth pyth dowr dhe wra lever 41 dhe mos dhe dhyso dhe vos dhe vargh, 42 dysk dhe dhyn ni an re a wra lever dhe dhyssel;
43 rag an onan-ma a wra genes gansow, rag an poos 44 a wra dhe vesa gans kig Adam, 45 yw araf dhe dhyski orth, orth y gila.”

**English:**
46 Their words, which I will repeat to these 47 that he whom I was following had spoken, 48 were not clear as to who spoke them;
49 but it was said: “Come with us along the bank to the right, 50 and you will find the passage 51 that a living person can climb.”
**Cornish:**
46 An gerow dhyn, a wra lever dhe dhyso dhe’n re-ma 47 a leveras gans an onan a wra leverow, 48 nyns o an re a wra leverys.
49 Mes leverys veu: “Genes gansoni orth an dowr dhe’n dhew, 50 ha mos dhe gavos an fordh 51 a wra possybyl dhe berson byw dhe dhyski.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 E s’io non fossi impedito dal sasso 53 che la cervice mia superba doma, 54 onde portar convienmi il viso basso,
55 cotesti, ch’ancor vive e non si noma, 56 guardere’ io, per veder s’i’ ’l conosco, 57 e per farlo pietoso a questa soma.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And if I were not hindered by the rock 53 that humbles my proud neck, 54 forcing me to keep my face down,
55 I would look at that man who is still alive and does not name himself, 56 to see if I know him, 57 and to move him to pity for this burden.
**Cornish:**
52 Ha mar a vea’f impedyes gans an garrek 53 a wra ow doma’m gwlavan bal, 54 owth onan dhe wra leverys dhe dhyso dhe dhyski’m an fas,
55 an onan-na, a wra byw ha nyns yw henwys, 56 a wra leverys ow, rag dhe weles mar a’m gwaraf, 57 ha dhe wul ow dhe vos trugarowgh dhe’n poos-ma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Io fui latino e nato d’un gran Tosco: 59 Guiglielmo Aldobrandesco fu mio padre; 60 non so se ’l nome suo già mai fu vosco.
query.result:
**English:**
58 I was Latin and born of a great Tuscan: 59 Guglielmo Aldobrandesco was my father; 60 I do not know if his name ever reached you.
**Cornish:**
58 Latin o’m ha genys gans Tuskan brassa: 59 Guglielmo Aldobrandesco o’m tas; 60 nyns ow kon mar a veu y hanow erbysi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 L’antico sangue e l’opere leggiadre 62 d’i miei maggior mi fer sì arrogante, 63 che, non pensando a la comune madre,
64 ogn’ uomo ebbi in despetto tanto avante, 65 ch’io ne mori’, come i Sanesi sanno, 66 e sallo in Campagnatico ogne fante.
query.result:
**English:**
61 My ancient blood and the noble deeds 62 of my ancestors made me so arrogant 63 that, not thinking of our common mother,
64 I held everyone in such great contempt 65 that I was killed for it, as the Sienese know, 66 and every foot-soldier in Campagnatico knows it.
**Cornish:**
61 An gow goth ha’n oberow brassa 62 a wrug ow kemmys bal, 63 owth onan na veu owth y vamm gyffres,
64 owth onan a veu ow kemmys bal dhe dhyski oll den, 65 owth onan a veu ow laddes, kepar ha’n Senesys a wra gwaraf, 66 ha’n oll fantys yn Campagnatico a wra gwaraf.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Io sono Omberto; e non pur a me danno 68 superbia fa, ché tutti miei consorti 69 ha ella tratti seco nel malanno.
query.result:
**English:**
67 I am Omberto; and pride brought ruin 68 not only to me, but it has dragged all my kinsmen 69 with it into misfortune.
**Cornish:**
67 Omberto yw ow hanow; ha nyns dhe’m niver 68 a wrug balder, rag ow holl gerens 69 a wra ow thosy gansow dhe’n anfortyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 E qui convien ch’io questo peso porti 71 per lei, tanto che a Dio si sodisfaccia, 72 poi ch’io nol fe’ tra ’ vivi, qui tra ’ morti».
query.result:
**English:**
70 And here I must bear this weight 71 for her, until I have made amends to God, 72 since I did not do so among the living, here among the dead.”
**Cornish:**
70 Ha hemma yw keus dhe dhyski an poos-ma 71 ragti, bys dhe wra ow sodhys dhe Dhew, 72 wosa na wrug ow tra’n bewnans, hemma tra’n merwys.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Ascoltando chinai in giù la faccia; 74 e un di lor, non questi che parlava, 75 si torse sotto il peso che li ’mpaccia,
76 e videmi e conobbemi e chiamava, 77 tenendo li occhi con fatica fisi 78 a me che tutto chin con loro andava.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Listening, I lowered my face; 74 and one of them, not the one who was speaking, 75 twisted under the weight that encumbers them,
76 and saw me and recognized me and called out, 77 keeping his eyes fixed on me with difficulty, 78 as I walked, head bowed, with them.
**Cornish:**
73 Wosa gwoslow, y'm gorra orth y'n fenester; 74 ha unn dhedha, na an onan o kewsel, 75 a omsettyas dan an boes na'n lettya,
76 ha'm gwelas ha'm aswon ha'm galwas, 77 ow tochya y'n lagha orthaf gans boes, 78 dell wosa ow tos orth gans an dus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 «Oh!», diss’ io lui, «non se’ tu Oderisi, 80 l’onor d’Agobbio e l’onor di quell’ arte 81 ch’alluminar chiamata è in Parisi?».
query.result:
**English:**
79 “Oh!” I said to him, “aren’t you Oderisi, 80 the honor of Gubbio and the honor of that art 81 that in Paris is called illuminating?”
**Cornish:**
79 “Oh!” mer a leveris, “na’th ti Oderisi, 80 an enor a Wubbio ha’n enor a’n art ma 81 a henwir yn Paris yn ‘leumyans?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 «Frate», diss’ elli, «più ridon le carte 83 che pennelleggia Franco Bolognese; 84 l’onore è tutto or suo, e mio in parte.
query.result:
**English:**
82 “Brother,” he said, “the cards that Franco Bolognese paints 83 laugh more than mine; 84 the honor is all his now, and mine in part.
**Cornish:**
82 “Froder,” mer a leveris, “moy a wra henna 83 chartes a benjellias Franco Bolognese; 84 an enor oll a-dho genna, ha’m rann a-barth.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Ben non sare’ io stato sì cortese 86 mentre ch’io vissi, per lo gran disio 87 de l’eccellenza ove mio core intese.
query.result:
**English:**
85 But I would not have been so courteous 86 while I was alive, because of the great desire 87 for excellence that my heart felt.
**Cornish:**
85 Mes na vynjy genna kemmys corjuss 86 pan omov vyw, rag an bras desyr 87 rag an excellens pan omov colon a-sens.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Di tal superbia qui si paga il fio; 89 e ancor non sarei qui, se non fosse 90 che, possendo peccar, mi volsi a Dio.
query.result:
**English:**
88 For such pride one pays the penalty here; 89 and I would not be here still, if it were not 90 that, having the power to sin, I turned to God.
**Cornish:**
88 Rag henna surperbia yma y tall an fro; 89 ha na vynjy genna yma, mar nas vyssy 90 ow possessa pecher, ow tos orth dhe Dew.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Oh vana gloria de l’umane posse! 92 com’ poco verde in su la cima dura, 93 se non è giunta da l’etati grosse!
94 Credette Cimabue ne la pittura 95 tener lo campo, e ora ha Giotto il grido, 96 sì che la fama di colui è scura.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Oh, vain glory of human powers! 92 How little green remains on the topmost branch, 93 if it is not reached by the heavy rains!
94 Cimabue thought he held the field in painting, 95 and now Giotto has the acclaim, 96 so that the fame of the former is obscured.
**Cornish:**
91 Oh, gwaneth vel a’n posse dyn! 92 Kemmys rudh a wra war an ughella, 93 mar nas vo gweythys gans an ethen bras!
94 Cimabue a grysyas yn an pentya 95 ow tenna an mayn, ha Giotto a-lemmyn an gri, 96 kepar ha’n fam a-dho a wra tywyll.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Così ha tolto l’uno a l’altro Guido 98 la gloria de la lingua; e forse è nato 99 chi l’uno e l’altro caccerà del nido.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Thus one Guido has taken from the other Guido 98 the glory of the language; and perhaps one is born 99 who will drive both of them from the nest.
**Cornish:**
97 Kepar hyn, unn Guido a gemeras dhe’n Guido aral 98 an gloyr a’n yeth; ha marnas yw genys 99 unn aral a wra’n kevra orth an neyth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Non è il mondan romore altro ch’un fiato 101 di vento, ch’or vien quinci e or vien quindi, 102 e muta nome perché muta lato.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Worldly fame is nothing but a breath 101 of wind, that now comes from here and now from there, 102 and changes its name because it changes direction.
**Cornish:**
100 An brys a’n bys na wra marnas unn enep 101 a gwyns, ow a dheu a-dhyworth hemma ha’n dhyworth henna, 102 ha’n chanjya y’n hanow rag y chanjya y’n fordh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Che voce avrai tu più, se vecchia scindi 104 da te la carne, che se fossi morto 105 anzi che tu lasciassi il ‘pappo’ e ’l ‘dindi’,
106 pria che passin mill’ anni? ch’è più corto 107 spazio a l’etterno, ch’un muover di ciglia 108 al cerchio che più tardi in cielo è torto.
query.result:
**English:**
103 What voice will you have more, if, when old, you separate 104 the flesh from you, than if you had died 105 before you left behind the “pap” and the “dinero”,
106 before a thousand years pass? For shorter 107 is the space to eternity than the movement of an eyelid 108 to the circle that is drawn slowest in the sky.
**Cornish:**
103 Py le a wra genvys moy, mar pan vo hen, 104 an kig dhe’th, ages pan vo marow 105 kyns vo hedhas an ‘pappo’ ha’n ‘dindi’,
106 kyns vo passya mil vledhen? Rag moy a wra gorra 107 an fordh dhe’n bysys, ages unn movyans a’n lagha 108 dhe’n kelgh a wra moy a-dhyworth yn an ebron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Colui che del cammin sì poco piglia 110 dinanzi a me, Toscana sonò tutta; 111 e ora a pena in Siena sen pispiglia,
112 ond’ era sire quando fu distrutta 113 la rabbia fiorentina, che superba 114 fu a quel tempo sì com’ ora è putta.
query.result:
**English:**
109 He who takes so little of the road 110 ahead of me, made all Tuscany resound; 111 and now hardly a whisper of him is heard in Siena,
112 where he was lord when the Florentine rage was destroyed, 113 which was as proud at that time as it is now vile.
**Cornish:**
109 An onan a gemer mar luyta a’n fordh 110 kynsaf vy, a wruk oll Toscani resona; 111 ha lemmyn a-bennans yn Siena ymonsa,
112 le mayn o syns pan vo distruys 113 an brys florenti, o vo surp 114 yn an termyn henna kepar ha’n wra putta lemmyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 La vostra nominanza è color d’erba, 116 che viene e va, e quei la discolora 117 per cui ella esce de la terra acerba».
query.result:
**English:**
115 Your fame is like the color of grass, 116 which comes and goes, and that discolors it 117 from which it emerges from the bitter earth.
**Cornish:**
115 Aga hanow es liw erbas, 116 ow a dheuth hag a veu, hagena 117 rag a dheuth a-ves an tir feth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 E io a lui: «Tuo vero dir m’incora 119 bona umiltà, e gran tumor m’appiani; 120 ma chi è quei di cui tu parlavi ora?».
query.result:
**English:**
118 And I to him: "Your true speech encourages me 119 with good humility, and levels my great pride; 120 but who is he of whom you were just speaking?".
**Cornish:**
118 Ha my a-dho: "Dha wir gwir a'm gorra 119 da vadhaleth da, ha'm gorra pur gallos; 120 mes pyw yw ena o kewsys tys a-nysy?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 «Quelli è», rispuose, «Provenzan Salvani; 122 ed è qui perché fu presuntüoso 123 a recar Siena tutta a le sue mani.
query.result:
**English:**
121 "That one is," he replied, "Provenzan Salvani; 122 and he is here because he was presumptuous 123 in trying to bring all of Siena under his control.
**Cornish:**
121 "Ena yw," a leveris, "Provenzan Salvani; 122 hag ev yw ama neb o ve presomptus 123 a hwithra oll Sen yn-dann y gila."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Ito è così e va, sanza riposo, 125 poi che morì; cotal moneta rende 126 a sodisfar chi è di là troppo oso».
query.result:
**English:**
124 He has been like this and goes on, without rest, 125 ever since he died; such payment does he render 126 to satisfy those who are too bold over there.
**Cornish:**
124 Ev yw kepar hyn ha mos, heb pos, 125 a-dhia wrug marow; kepar moneth a wra 126 rag sodhfya neb a vydh re beus ow tros gallos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 E io: «Se quello spirito ch’attende, 128 pria che si penta, l’orlo de la vita, 129 qua giù dimora e qua sù non ascende,
130 se buona orazïon lui non aita, 131 prima che passi tempo quanto visse, 132 come fu la venuta lui largita?».
query.result:
**English:**
127 And I: "If that spirit which awaits, 128 before it repents, the end of life, 129 dwells down here and does not ascend above,
130 unless good prayers help it, 131 before as much time passes as it lived, 132 how was its coming here granted to it?".
**Cornish:**
127 Ha my: "Mar an sperys na wra gorthys, 128 kyns na wra edifyes, an diwedh byw, 129 ow a wra trig ama ha na wra sevel,
130 mar na wra gwedhvos da ow kovsorta, 131 kyns na wra tremena kyns termyn y vewnans, 132 pyth yw ow dos ow dheuth ama?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Più non dirò, e scuro so che parlo; 140 ma poco tempo andrà, che ’ tuoi vicini 141 faranno sì che tu potrai chiosarlo.
query.result:
**English:**
139 I will say no more, and I know that I speak obscurely; 140 but a short time will pass before your neighbors 141 will act in such a way that you will be able to interpret it.
**Cornish:**
139 Na wra leverel moy, ha'm owth yw dywyth; 140 mes byghan termyn a wra kyns, dha nessa, 141 a wra gweles kepar pyth ylli kewsel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 Quest’ opera li tolse quei confini».
query.result:
**English:**
142 This work removed those limits for him.
**Cornish:**
142 An ober ma a wrug gorra an termennow.
